title: God's Covenant with Abraham
shortSummary: In Genesis 17, God establishes a covenant with Abram, renaming him Abraham and promising to make him the father of many nations. This chapter introduces the covenant sign of circumcision and foretells the birth of Isaac, the child of promise through Sarah. It highlights God's faithfulness and the importance of obedience in the covenant relationship.

keyCharacters.name: Abraham
keyCharacters.description: Originally Abram, he is the patriarch who receives God's covenant promise to become the father of many nations.

keyCharacters.name: Sarah
keyCharacters.description: Abraham's wife, originally named Sarai, who is promised by God to bear a son named Isaac despite her old age.

keyCharacters.name: Ishmael
keyCharacters.description: Abraham's son by Hagar, who is blessed by God but not the child of the covenant.

definitions.definition: A solemn agreement between God and man, often involving promises and obligations.
The physical removal of the foreskin of the male genitalia, instituted as the sign of the covenant between God and Abraham's descendants.
A covenant that is perpetual and unending, signifying God's enduring promise to Abraham and his descendants.
Descendants or offspring, often used in the Bible to refer to the line of Abraham.

outline.heading: God's Appearance and Covenant Promise
outline.description: God appears to Abram, renames him Abraham, and promises to make him exceedingly fruitful, establishing an everlasting covenant with him and his descendants.

outline.heading: The Covenant of Circumcision
outline.description: God commands Abraham and his descendants to keep the covenant through circumcision as a lasting sign of their relationship with Him.

outline.heading: Renaming of Sarai to Sarah and Promise of Isaac
outline.description: God changes Sarai's name to Sarah and promises that she will bear a son, Isaac, through whom the covenant will be established.

outline.heading: Abraham's Immediate Obedience
outline.description: Abraham obeys God's command by circumcising himself, Ishmael, and all the males in his household on the same day, demonstrating faith and submission.

application: Trust in God's promises even when circumstances seem impossible, as Abraham did regarding the birth of Isaac.
Obedience to God's commands is essential in maintaining a covenant relationship with Him, exemplified by Abraham's immediate action to circumcise his household.
Recognize the importance of spiritual identity and commitment, symbolized by the covenant sign of circumcision.
Remember that God's promises often require patience and faithfulness across generations.

keyVerses.text: And when Abram was ninety years old and nine, the LORD appeared to Abram, and said unto him, I am the Almighty God; walk before me, and be thou perfect.
keyVerses.significance: God reveals Himself as Almighty and calls Abraham to live a life of faithful obedience.

keyVerses.text: Neither shall thy name any more be called Abram, but thy name shall be Abraham; for a father of many nations have I made thee.
keyVerses.significance: The renaming signifies a new identity and mission as the father of many nations under God's covenant.

keyVerses.text: This is my covenant, which ye shall keep, between me and you and thy seed after thee; Every man child among you shall be circumcised.
keyVerses.significance: Circumcision is instituted as the physical sign of the covenant, marking God's chosen people.

keyVerses.text: And God said, Sarah thy wife shall bear thee a son indeed; and thou shalt call his name Isaac: and I will establish my covenant with him for an everlasting covenant, and with his seed after him.
keyVerses.significance: God confirms the promise of a son through Sarah, establishing the covenant line through Isaac.
